ops.insert: Start by clapping 5 times then use fingers to count.
What do you see? I see sheep
? The sheep are glad! Let’s count the sheep.
Write numbers under the sheep while counting.
One sheep, two sheep, three sheep, four sheep, five sheep! Can you count the sheep? Write and count!
Encourage student to count and write numbers.

- You can count with their body by clapping five times, then counting with the hand by showing five fingers. Alternatively, tap your head and shoulders!
- If the student is too young to write the numbers, the item can be circled while counting. 
- Remember to erase the notations you make before the students turn to count, write or circle.    
- Put emphasis on the “S” in cats so student understands that the word changes when there is more than one.
Let’s build/make something together! What can we build/make?
Click and drag objects from each side to the middle to create desired object.
Now it’s your turn. Can you build/make a
Click Reset button and enable student’s mouse.
Oh no!  Is this right? How can we fix
You did it! What is it?
Click on one of the objects to reveal the hidden images.
Who do I see here? I see a (boy/girl) here!
Now it’s your turn. Do you see a
Student clicks on objects to reveal the hidden images behind them.
Who do you see here? I see a (boy/girl) here.
Use the same sentence each time an image is revealed, then count all the images separately.
One boy/girl, two boys/girls, three boys/girls...

- If counting, put a strong emphasis on plurals by exaggerating the changes to the word in plural, and making sure the student repeats it properly.  
- You may use fingers when counting.
- If the student gets stuck, click objects to reveal the hidden images.
I'm so glad you are here. I am
). Say Hi to (Fix/Paul/Flupe). Say hi to me!
Make characters say “Hi” using their menus.
Ask Students to greet characters and teacher.
Let’s have fun! Let’s have fun with

- Click the buttons below each character to have them respond to students or to move/bounce around. 
 - Wave while saying

to the characters with the students.
- You can place an open hand behind the ear to show that they want the child to say something.
- Throw hands up in the air when saying
- Movement for Flupe: Place both hands touching the forehead with palms facing out and wiggle fingers.
A dragon! Be careful! SHHH - Don’t wake the dragon.
Take first item from under the dragon.
Student drags the item from under the dragon.
What have you got? I’ve got a ____!
Continue like this until the dragon wakes up.

- Teacher and student click on the images and drag them into the treasure chest until the dragon 'wakes up’.
 - If there are duplicate items, use them to practice counting!
- Use suspenseful and surprised TPR when playing this game. 
- There is some new language that they
need to know for this game that we don’t need to emphasize.
The students screens are dark - they can only see the area inside the red circle(s) on your screen.
We’re at Granny Fix’s house! She needs (object).
Ask students to move their mouse around i.e. shine their torch.
Click on the red circle representing the student’s mouse

onRedCircle.insert: Is this what Granny Fix is looking for?
If not, click the X and keep looking. If yes, click the tick.
Hurray! Granny Fix has found her (object)!
Select a new object to find and repeat.

ops.insert:
You can act out words!
- Movement for

: open and close hands quickly showing how something shines. 
- Movement for

place hands cupped over the eyes and point forward.
- Movement for
Point to yourself and point to one eye.
Play keys one by one while reviewing all vocab.
Girl, boy, hat, tree, book, donkey, rabbit.
Click on Start button to activate the correct/incorrect feedback and prompt the students with the first note/word to play.
Where is the (hat, tree, girl, tree, hat, hat, hat)? The____ is here!
Prompt students to play the highlighted notes one by one.
Hat, tree, girl, tree, hat, hat, hat!
Play/sing the full tune again at a faster pace to complete the activity.
- As you demonstrate the keys, you may use movements from the songs to help the student remember the words.

- To provide feedback to students, use the green and red feedback, and the pictures inside, to see when students correctly or incorrectly click their piano keys. 
- Teacher must remember to enunciate and use visual cues if the student doesn’t recall the vocabulary word. 
- Younger students may have trouble with clicking keys fast enough to hear the tune. When student has had a few tries to click keys/review vocab, teacher can sing/play the tune before moving on to the next module.
The dog, the cat, and the sheep are in the tub! But there are
What can we use to plug the tub?
We can plug the tub with a
! Do you want a ___? YES - I want a ____.
Click on the item in your sidebar to ‘give’ it to the student. This will make it draggable in the students sidebar.
Click and drag to plug the hole in the tub!
Repeat for all holes in the tub.
Wonderful! You plugged the tub with a
Circle/point to the images inside the wheel while the student reviews words.
I see (a tub, a house, a tree, a book, sad Paul, glad Paul).
Circle/point to the image to the right of the wheel.
What do you see here? I see______. Let’s spin the wheel and find the match!
Click the Go! button to start the wheel.
Now it’s your turn! Can you spin the wheel? Yes, I can spin the wheel!
Choose an image in the sidebar for the wheel to stop on.
What’s this? I know! This is a______. Is it a match? Yes/No.

- Circle or point to the image on the right so student can see that they must match that image with the one in the wheel. 
- You choose when the student gets it right. Make the wheel land on the incorrect answer a few times to review more words.
- Use gestures for spin and stop to help students understand the activity. 
- Don’t forget to praise their efforts!
